channel.title: So did anyone actually manage to sneak past the tentacle without taking a hit?
channel.description:
Because I sure as hell didn't. In fact, running it was more effective than sneaking. Every time I tried sneaking (crouch-moving) it just knew where I was and killed me. I only got past by rushing it.
Also the perfectly uniform crushed railings look weird as hell.
Oh and the 'banging' noises weren't loud enough, they should be deafening.
It was perhaps the most disappointing bit for me.

item.dc:creator: sersoft
item.description:
nefatheape:

This seems to be one of the more common “I’m trying to play it like HL and it isn’t working” problems.

BMS is simply a different game; sometimes the techniques that worked in HL won’t work in BMS – sometimes intentionally, sometimes not. I think its fun trying to figure out the new stuff. We’ve all beaten the tentacle a gajillion times in HL, so it’s nice to have it be a little different IMO.

so much this

In half life you have to crawl as slowly as possible and throw nades to the other side of the room if the tentacle so much as tickles your nipples, you’re dead. In black mesa it’s the total opposite… fuck the grenades and the crouching, just run as fast as you can and it won’t do any damage, even if you do get hit it will take away like 3hp… Although I suspect this will be fixed soon though.

item.dc:creator: Lanthanide
item.description:
tankboi:

Not sure if I am remembering this correctly, but I thought in HL1 you could make the tenticles completely recede into the hole by throwing grenades into it?? I am sure thats how i got past it in the first game. In BM I found the grenades ineffective…

Hmm, I believe you might have been able to get 1 head at a time to go back down if you shot them enough, but they didn’t stay down for long.

One thing I did remember though, is that in HL1 after a long enough time with silence the tentacles would stop attacking completely, and would rise up into the air and make that sort of groaning noise, with the raspy throat-clearing noises, and you could navigate around the platforms without the need for grenades or other distractions as long as you were completely silent (crouching or walking). That doesn’t seem to happen in BM - they keep attacking the floor, eventually just choosing random locations.

item.title: So did anyone actually manage to sneak past the tentacle without taking a hit?
item.dc:creator: bmesakoki
item.description:
The trick to getting past the tentacles without being hit is definitely to crouch walk to each of the ladders. Just be generous with the grenades. The tentacles are on a timer, so even if you don’t make any noise after tossing a grenade, they get bored and start knocking around again. It takes patience, but is doable.

One trick is to hang out half-way on a ladder — you won’t always avoid tentacles, but if they come knocking a bit after you throw grenade, it gives you time to throw another one onto a different level. To make getting past the wooden barricades easier, I toss a grenade their way first to take care of those road blocks so I don’t have to worry about it once I reach that floor.

I probably use 4 grenades (maybe 5 on the way back up) per door. There’s enough refills along the way to keep you stockpiled.

item.title: So did anyone actually manage to sneak past the tentacle without taking a hit?
item.dc:creator: Lanthanide
item.description:
I did get hit and killed by it, but only while learning how to use the grenades appropriately.

The thing with the tentacles is that when you throw a grenade, one of the heads will directly hit the spot that it exploded at, another will strike just slightly to the right of it, maybe 10 degrees, and the 3rd will be about 70-80 degrees to the left of the first one. So if you throw a grenade at some spot away from you on the same level, there’s a good chance that the 3rd head will still strike you.

The real way to handle this is to throw grenades onto different levels, then there’s no chance it’ll hurt you at all.

Going down the silo is therefore easy, as you can simply throw it a level or two below where you need to be (and break up the wooden boards with grenades from a distance, too). Coming back up from the bottom is a lot harder though, as you’re not able to throw grenades to the level above. In the end, I found throwing a grenade and simply sprinting the easiest way to get back to the top.

It’s a pity BM doesn’t have walking like HL1 did, as that is the ‘proper’ way to finish this section (not crouching, although crouching up/down HL1 ladders lets you climb them silently, whereas walking didn’t).
